Returns the "sign" of the integer as another integer: `1` for positive numbers,
`-1` for negative numbers, and `0` for `0`.

type: ℤ → ℤ
name: Int.sign
docString:
Returns the "sign" of the integer as another integer: `1` for positive numbers,
`-1` for negative numbers, and `0` for `0`.

For any inner product space `(E, ⟨·, ·⟩)` over commutative scalar type `𝕜`, ⟨0, x⟩ = 0 for all `x ∈ E`.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : RCLike 𝕜] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : InnerProductSpace 𝕜 E]
  (x : E), ⟪0, x⟫_𝕜 = 0
name: inner_zero_left
docString: For any inner product space `(E, ⟨·, ·⟩)` over commutative scalar type `𝕜`, ⟨0, x⟩ = 0 for all `x ∈ E`.

This theorem, `inner_zero_left`, states that for any scalar type `𝕜` and any normed add commutative group `E` with an inner product space over `𝕜`, the inner product of the zero vector and any vector `x` in `E` is always zero. This is a fundamental property of inner product spaces, essentially stating that the zero vector is orthogonal to all other vectors.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : RCLike 𝕜] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : InnerProductSpace 𝕜 E]
  (x : E), ⟪0, x⟫_𝕜 = 0
name: inner_zero_left
docString: This theorem, `inner_zero_left`, states that for any scalar type `𝕜` and any normed add commutative group `E` with an inner product space over `𝕜`, the inner product of the zero vector and any vector `x` in `E` is always zero. This is a fundamental property of inner product spaces, essentially stating that the zero vector is orthogonal to all other vectors.

Characterization of minimizers for the projection on a convex set in a real inner product
space.

type:
∀ {F : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ F] {K : Set F},
  Convex ℝ K → ∀ {u v : F}, v ∈ K → (‖u - v‖ = ⨅ w, ‖u - ↑w‖ ↔ ∀ w ∈ K, ⟪u - v, w - v⟫_ℝ ≤ 0)
name: norm_eq_iInf_iff_real_inner_le_zero
docString:
Characterization of minimizers for the projection on a convex set in a real inner product
space.

Given a `PseudoMetricSpace` and `ProperSpace` TYPE `α` with point `x`, real number `r`, and closed set `s`, if `s ⊆ ball x r`, then there exists `r' < r` such that `s ⊆ ball x r'`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace α] [inst_1 : ProperSpace α] {x : α} {r : ℝ} {s : Set α},
  IsClosed s → s ⊆ Metric.ball x r → ∃ r' < r, s ⊆ Metric.ball x r'
name: exists_lt_subset_ball
docString: Given a `PseudoMetricSpace` and `ProperSpace` TYPE `α` with point `x`, real number `r`, and closed set `s`, if `s ⊆ ball x r`, then there exists `r' < r` such that `s ⊆ ball x r'`.

The theorem `StrictConvexOn.eq_of_isMinOn` states that for any strictly convex function `f` from a set `s` in a linearly ordered field `𝕜`, if the function `f` has a global minimum on `s` at two different points `x` and `y`, then `x` and `y` must be the same. This means a strictly convex function can have at most one global minimum.

name: StrictConvexOn.eq_of_isMinOn
docString: The theorem `StrictConvexOn.eq_of_isMinOn` states that for any strictly convex function `f` from a set `s` in a linearly ordered field `𝕜`, if the function `f` has a global minimum on `s` at two different points `x` and `y`, then `x` and `y` must be the same. This means a strictly convex function can have at most one global minimum.

Default definition of `min`.

type: {α : Type u} → [inst : LE α] → [inst : DecidableRel fun x x_1 => x ≤ x_1] → α → α → α
name: minDefault
docString: Default definition of `min`.

Corresponds to `dist_pos`.

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_2} {β : ι → Type u_3} [inst : Fintype ι] [inst_1 : (i : ι) → DecidableEq (β i)] {x y : (i : ι) → β i},
  0 < hammingDist x y ↔ x ≠ y
name: hammingDist_pos
docString: Corresponds to `dist_pos`.

The default priority for spawned tasks, also the lowest priority: `0`.

type: Task.Priority
name: Task.Priority.default
docString: The default priority for spawned tasks, also the lowest priority: `0`.

**Minimum principle** for concave functions. If a function `f` is concave on the convex hull of
`s`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `convexHull 𝕜 s` lies in `s`.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {β : Type u_4} [inst : LinearOrderedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup β] [inst_3 : Module 𝕜 E] [inst_4 : Module 𝕜 β] [inst_5 : OrderedSMul 𝕜 β]
  {s : Set E} {f : E → β}, ConcaveOn 𝕜 ((convexHull 𝕜) s) f → ∀ {x : E}, x ∈ (convexHull 𝕜) s → ∃ y ∈ s, f y ≤ f x
name: ConcaveOn.exists_le_of_mem_convexHull
docString:
**Minimum principle** for concave functions. If a function `f` is concave on the convex hull of
`s`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `convexHull 𝕜 s` lies in `s`.

Given a point `x` in a product space `Π (n : ℕ), E n`, and `s` a subset of this space, then
`shortestPrefixDiff x s` if the smallest `n` for which there is no element of `s` having the same
prefix of length `n` as `x`. If there is no such `n`, then use `0` by convention.

type: {E : ℕ → Type u_2} → ((n : ℕ) → E n) → Set ((n : ℕ) → E n) → ℕ
name: PiNat.shortestPrefixDiff
docString:
Given a point `x` in a product space `Π (n : ℕ), E n`, and `s` a subset of this space, then
`shortestPrefixDiff x s` if the smallest `n` for which there is no element of `s` having the same
prefix of length `n` as `x`. If there is no such `n`, then use `0` by convention.

The rank of a module as a natural number.

Defined by convention to be `0` if the space has infinite rank.

For a vector space `M` over a field `R`, this is the same as the finite dimension
of `M` over `R`.

type: (R : Type u_1) → (M : Type u_2) → [inst : Semiring R] → [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] → [inst : Module R M] → ℕ
name: FiniteDimensional.finrank
docString:
The rank of a module as a natural number.

Defined by convention to be `0` if the space has infinite rank.

For a vector space `M` over a field `R`, this is the same as the finite dimension
of `M` over `R`.

Given a point `x` in a product space `Π (n : ℕ), E n`, and `s` a subset of this space, then
`longestPrefix x s` if the largest `n` for which there is an element of `s` having the same
prefix of length `n` as `x`. If there is no such `n`, use `0` by convention.

type: {E : ℕ → Type u_2} → ((n : ℕ) → E n) → Set ((n : ℕ) → E n) → ℕ
name: PiNat.longestPrefix
docString:
Given a point `x` in a product space `Π (n : ℕ), E n`, and `s` a subset of this space, then
`longestPrefix x s` if the largest `n` for which there is an element of `s` having the same
prefix of length `n` as `x`. If there is no such `n`, use `0` by convention.

specialized cases distinction for an arrow in the category of 0-length type vectors

type:
{β : TypeVec.Arrow Fin2.elim0 Fin2.elim0 → Sort u_1} →

**Minimum principle** for concave functions on a segment. If a function `f` is concave on the
segment `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {β : Type u_4} [inst : LinearOrderedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup β] [inst_3 : Module 𝕜 E] [inst_4 : Module 𝕜 β] [inst_5 : OrderedSMul 𝕜 β]
  {f : E → β} {x y z : E}, ConcaveOn 𝕜 (segment 𝕜 x y) f → z ∈ segment 𝕜 x y → min (f x) (f y) ≤ f z
name: ConcaveOn.min_le_of_mem_segment
docString:
**Minimum principle** for concave functions on a segment. If a function `f` is concave on the
segment `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

Corresponds to `zero_eq_dist`.

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_2} {β : ι → Type u_3} [inst : Fintype ι] [inst_1 : (i : ι) → DecidableEq (β i)] {x y : (i : ι) → β i},
  0 = hammingDist x y ↔ x = y
name: hamming_zero_eq_dist
docString: Corresponds to `zero_eq_dist`.

**Minimum principle** for concave functions on an interval. If a function `f` is concave on the
interval `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} {β : Type u_4} [inst : LinearOrderedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup β]
  [inst_2 : Module 𝕜 β] [inst_3 : OrderedSMul 𝕜 β] {f : 𝕜 → β} {x y z : 𝕜},
  ConcaveOn 𝕜 (Set.Icc x y) f → z ∈ Set.Icc x y → min (f x) (f y) ≤ f z
name: ConcaveOn.min_le_of_mem_Icc
docString:
**Minimum principle** for concave functions on an interval. If a function `f` is concave on the
interval `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

`toReal x` returns `x` if it is real, `0` otherwise.

type: ENNReal → ℝ
name: ENNReal.toReal
docString: `toReal x` returns `x` if it is real, `0` otherwise.

The minimum function is equivalent to the one you get from `minOfLe`.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [self : LinearOrderedCommGroup α] (a b : α), min a b = if a ≤ b then a else b
name: LinearOrderedCommGroup.min_def
docString: The minimum function is equivalent to the one you get from `minOfLe`.

`SimpleFunc.integral` and `SimpleFunc.lintegral` agree when the integrand has type
`α →ₛ ℝ≥0∞`. But since `ℝ≥0∞` is not a `NormedSpace`, we need some form of coercion.
See `integral_eq_lintegral` for a simpler version.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] {m : MeasurableSpace α} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α}
  {f : MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc α E} {g : E → ENNReal},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable ↑f →
    g 0 = 0 →
      (∀ (b : E), g b ≠ ⊤) →
        MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc.integral μ (MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc.map (ENNReal.toReal ∘ g) f) =
          ENNReal.toReal (∫⁻ (a : α), g (↑f a) ∂μ)
name: MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc.integral_eq_lintegral'
docString:
`SimpleFunc.integral` and `SimpleFunc.lintegral` agree when the integrand has type
`α →ₛ ℝ≥0∞`. But since `ℝ≥0∞` is not a `NormedSpace`, we need some form of coercion.
See `integral_eq_lintegral` for a simpler version.

The minimum operation: `min x y`.

type: {α : Type u} → [self : Min α] → α → α → α
name: Min.min
docString: The minimum operation: `min x y`.

The space of functions `Fin 2 → α` is equivalent to `α × α`. See also `piFinTwoEquiv` and
`prodEquivPiFinTwo`.

type: (α : Type u_1) → (Fin 2 → α) ≃ α × α
name: finTwoArrowEquiv
docString:
The space of functions `Fin 2 → α` is equivalent to `α × α`. See also `piFinTwoEquiv` and
`prodEquivPiFinTwo`.

A type endowed with `0` and unary `-` is an `NegZeroClass`, if it admits an
injective map that preserves `0` and unary `-` to an `NegZeroClass`.

type:
{M₁ : Type u_1} →
  {M₂ : Type u_2} →
    [inst : Zero M₁] →
      [inst_1 : Neg M₁] →
        [inst_2 : NegZeroClass M₂] →
          (f : M₁ → M₂) → Function.Injective f → f 0 = 0 → (∀ (x : M₁), f (-x) = -f x) → NegZeroClass M₁
name: Function.Injective.negZeroClass
docString:
A type endowed with `0` and unary `-` is an `NegZeroClass`, if it admits an
injective map that preserves `0` and unary `-` to an `NegZeroClass`.

Corresponds to `dist_zero_right`.

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_2} {β : ι → Type u_3} [inst : Fintype ι] [inst_1 : (i : ι) → DecidableEq (β i)]
  [inst_2 : (i : ι) → Zero (β i)] (x : (i : ι) → β i), hammingDist x 0 = hammingNorm x
name: hammingDist_zero_right
docString: Corresponds to `dist_zero_right`.
